hero.title: Hangul Automata
hero.subtitle: Understanding Hangul Input Through Finite Automata
hero.description: From DFA to Mealy Machine to Korean input — explore how automata theory powers Hangul character composition, visualized step by step.

dfa.title: DFA — Deterministic Finite Automaton
dfa.description: A DFA is the most fundamental automaton that determines whether an input string belongs to a specific pattern.
dfa.theoryPre: A DFA is defined as a 5-tuple

mealy.title: Mealy Machine — Automaton with Output
mealy.description: Unlike a DFA, a Mealy Machine produces output during state transitions, generating a transformed string instead of accept/reject decisions.
mealy.theoryPre: A Mealy Machine is defined as a 6-tuple

hangul.title: Korean Converter — Mealy Machine in Practice
hangul.description: A 10-state Mealy Machine converts English key inputs to Korean characters. The composition rules of initial, medial, and final consonants are modeled as state transitions.

dokkaebi.title: Dokkaebi Phenomenon
dokkaebi.description: When a vowel follows a final consonant (batchim), the consonant moves to become the initial consonant of the next syllable. This is the most fascinating behavior of Korean input.
dokkaebi.explanation: This occurs in the Mealy Machine when a vowel input arrives at a final consonant state (K, N, R, L). The output code 'd' deletes the previous final consonant and repositions it as the initial consonant of the new syllable.

footer.description: Visualizing Hangul input principles through automata theory
footer.builtWith: Built with Next.js, React Flow, Motion
